SivaLabs Marketplace: Supercharge Spring Boot Development with Claude Code

Jan 4, 2026
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Claude Code has rapidly become a powerful AI-powered development companion, and its extensibility through plugins and MCP servers opens up incredible possibilities for specialized development workflows. Enter SivaLabs Marketplace - a curated collection of plugins designed specifically for Java and Spring Boot developers.

Created by K. Siva Prasad Reddy (sivalabs), a well-known Spring Boot author and educator, this marketplace brings enterprise Java development patterns directly into your AI-assisted coding experience.

What is SivaLabs Marketplace?

Section titled “What is SivaLabs Marketplace?”

SivaLabs Marketplace is a plugin collection for Claude Code that focuses on Spring Boot application development using the Java, Spring Boot, and Spring Data JPA technology stack. It provides specialized skills that automate common development tasks while following established best practices and architectural patterns.

The marketplace is currently in active development (as of January 2026) and includes the spring-boot-dev plugin as its flagship offering.

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

Getting started with SivaLabs Marketplace is straightforward:

After installation, you can verify the plugin and its skills are available using the /plugins command in Claude CLI.

Available Skills

Section titled “Available Skills”

The spring-boot-dev plugin includes five specialized skills that streamline Spring Boot development:

1. spring-boot-package-structure-creator

Section titled “1. spring-boot-package-structure-creator”

Creates the recommended package structure for Spring Boot projects following best practices. This skill ensures your project starts with a solid architectural foundation.

2. jpa-entity-creator

Section titled “2. jpa-entity-creator”

Automates the creation of JPA entities with proper annotations, relationships, and best practices. Simply describe your entity requirements, and the skill generates production-ready entity classes.

3. spring-data-jpa-repo-creator

Section titled “3. spring-data-jpa-repo-creator”

Generates Spring Data JPA repository interfaces for your entities, including custom query methods when needed.

4. spring-service-creator

Section titled “4. spring-service-creator”

Creates Spring service layer classes with proper dependency injection, transaction management, and business logic separation.

5. spring-rest-api-creator

Section titled “5. spring-rest-api-creator”

Builds Spring MVC REST API controllers with appropriate annotations, request/response handling, and validation.

Practical Example

Section titled “Practical Example”

Here’s how you can use SivaLabs Marketplace to quickly build a CRUD REST API:

  1. Create a Spring Boot project with Web, Validation, Spring Data JPA, and H2 dependencies
  2. In Claude CLI, prompt: “Implement CRUD REST API for Person with id, name, email and phone fields”
  3. The plugin will automatically generate:
    • JPA Entity (Person.java)
    • Repository interface (PersonRepository.java)
    • Service layer (PersonService.java)
    • REST Controller (PersonController.java)

Each generated component follows Spring Boot best practices and integrates seamlessly with the others.

Included MCP Server

Section titled “Included MCP Server”

The marketplace also includes the context7 MCP server, which provides general library documentation lookup capabilities. This enhances Claude Code’s ability to reference official Spring documentation and other libraries during development.

Best Practices and Use Cases

Section titled “Best Practices and Use Cases”

When to Use SivaLabs Marketplace

Section titled “When to Use SivaLabs Marketplace”
  • New Spring Boot Projects: Quickly scaffold properly structured projects
  • CRUD Operations: Generate standard create, read, update, delete APIs
  • Learning Spring Boot: See best practices in generated code
  • Prototyping: Rapidly build working APIs for testing and validation

Tips for Effective Use

Section titled “Tips for Effective Use”
  1. Start with Package Structure: Use spring-boot-package-structure-creator first to establish your project layout
  2. Describe Entities Clearly: When using jpa-entity-creator, provide detailed field specifications including types, constraints, and relationships
  3. Review Generated Code: While the plugins follow best practices, always review and adjust generated code to match your specific requirements
  4. Use Context7: Leverage the included MCP server for accessing up-to-date Spring documentation

Compound Engineering Plugin: Official Claude Code Plugin That Makes Each Unit of Engineering Work Easier

Jan 3, 2026
Vibe Sparking

Compound Engineering Plugin: Official Claude Code Plugin That Makes Each Unit of Engineering Work Easier

Section titled “Compound Engineering Plugin: Official Claude Code Plugin That Makes Each Unit of Engineering Work Easier”

“Each unit of engineering work should make subsequent units easier—not harder.”

In traditional software development, every feature added makes the next feature harder to build. More code means more edge cases, more interdependencies, and more complexity. This accumulation of technical debt is the default trajectory for most codebases.

EveryInc’s compound-engineering-plugin for Claude Code inverts this paradigm. It implements a compound engineering methodology where each unit of work makes future work easier through a systematic learning loop.

Introduction and Key Features

Section titled “Introduction and Key Features”

The compound-engineering-plugin is an official Claude Code plugin developed by EveryInc that orchestrates AI agents to plan, write, review, and compound engineering knowledge. The plugin embodies a revolutionary approach to software development where:

  • 80% of effort goes into planning and review - ensuring thorough understanding before code is written
  • 20% goes into execution - leveraging AI agents for code generation
  • Knowledge compounds over time - each lesson learned feeds back into the system

Key Highlights

Section titled “Key Highlights”
FeatureDescription
Four-Step WorkflowPlan → Work → Review → Compound → Repeat
Multi-Agent OrchestrationParallel agents handle research, implementation, and review
Knowledge CompoundingLearnings are systematically captured and reused
Worktree ManagementIsolated development environments for each feature
Open SourceMIT licensed, fully auditable and customizable

Prerequisites, Installation and Configuration

Section titled “Prerequisites, Installation and Configuration”

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”
  • Claude Code installed and configured
  • Git for worktree management
  • GitHub CLI (gh) for repository operations

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

The installation process is straightforward:

Initial Configuration

Section titled “Initial Configuration”

Once installed, the plugin provides four main workflow commands:

CommandPurpose
/workflows:planTurn feature ideas into detailed implementation plans
/workflows:workExecute plans with worktrees and task tracking
/workflows:reviewMulti-agent code review before merging
/workflows:compoundDocument learnings to make future work easier

Recommended Scenarios and Best Practices

Section titled “Recommended Scenarios and Best Practices”

When to Use Compound Engineering

Section titled “When to Use Compound Engineering”

This methodology excels in these scenarios:

  1. Solo Developers Building Products - One developer can achieve what traditionally required a team of five
  2. Complex Feature Development - Multi-component features that require careful planning
  3. Knowledge-Intensive Codebases - Projects where context and patterns matter significantly
  4. Long-Term Projects - Projects where compound effects have time to accumulate

Daily Workflow Example

Section titled “Daily Workflow Example”

Here’s how a typical compound engineering session flows:

Step 1: Plan (80% of the value)

Section titled “Step 1: Plan (80% of the value)”

The agent:

  • Researches the codebase and commit history
  • Scours the internet for best practices
  • Synthesizes a detailed implementation plan
  • Identifies potential pitfalls and edge cases

Step 2: Work (20% of the value)

Section titled “Step 2: Work (20% of the value)”

The agent:

  • Creates an isolated worktree
  • Implements according to the plan
  • Writes tests alongside code
  • Tracks task completion

Step 3: Review (Critical checkpoint)

Section titled “Step 3: Review (Critical checkpoint)”

Multiple agents:

  • Review the code independently
  • Catch issues and suggest improvements
  • Evaluate against established patterns
  • Verify all acceptance criteria

Step 4: Compound (The magic happens)

Section titled “Step 4: Compound (The magic happens)”

The agent:

  • Documents lessons learned
  • Captures new patterns discovered
  • Updates project knowledge base
  • Feeds insights back into the system

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”
  1. Never skip the Plan phase - This is where most value is created
  2. Always Review before merging - Multiple perspectives catch more issues
  3. Document everything - Future agents depend on this knowledge
  4. Trust the process - The compound effect takes time to manifest

Precautions, FAQ, and Troubleshooting

Section titled “Precautions, FAQ, and Troubleshooting”

Important Considerations

Section titled “Important Considerations”

⚠️ Learning Curve

The compound engineering approach requires a mindset shift. Traditional developers accustomed to “just coding” may find the emphasis on planning unfamiliar.

⚠️ Initial Investment

The first few cycles will feel slower than traditional development. This is normal - you’re building the knowledge foundation that future cycles will leverage.

⚠️ Tool Requirements

Full benefits require Claude Code with the plugin installed. The methodology is tool-agnostic in theory but optimized for this stack.

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: Is this only for solo developers?

A: No. While Every uses it to enable solo developers to build complex products, teams can benefit even more from the systematic knowledge capture and multi-agent review process.

Q: Does this work with existing codebases?

A: Yes. The Plan phase includes researching your existing codebase, making it effective for both greenfield and brownfield projects.

Q: Can I use this with other AI coding tools?

A: The plugin is designed for Claude Code, but the compound engineering philosophy is tool-agnostic. Some Every team members also use OpenAI’s Codex CLI.

Q: What happens if the plan is wrong?

A: The Review and Compound phases capture why the plan didn’t work, feeding that learning back into future planning cycles.

Troubleshooting

Section titled “Troubleshooting”
IssueSolution
Plugin not foundEnsure marketplace is added before installing
Worktree conflictsClean up existing worktrees with git worktree prune
Agent hallucinationsUse Review phase with multiple agents to catch issues
Slow performanceConsider reducing research scope in Plan phase

Key Differentiators

Section titled “Key Differentiators”

  1. Knowledge Compounding as First-Class Citizen - Most tools focus on code generation; compound engineering focuses on making future work easier

  2. Multi-Agent Review - Leverages multiple AI perspectives to catch issues that single-agent approaches miss

  3. Systematic Learning Loop - Every lesson is captured and fed back into the system

  4. 80/20 Planning-to-Execution Ratio - Inverts the traditional emphasis on coding speed

Integration Possibilities

Section titled “Integration Possibilities”

The compound engineering plugin can integrate with:

  • CI/CD pipelines - Use Review phase as a gate before deployment
  • Documentation tools - Automatically feed Compound outputs into knowledge bases
  • Project management - Track worktrees as tasks/features
  • Code quality tools - Combine with linters, formatters, and security scanners

Real-World Impact

Section titled “Real-World Impact”

EveryInc runs five software products in-house, each primarily built and run by a single person using compound engineering:

“Today, if your AI is used right, a single developer can do the work of five developers a few years ago, based on our experience at Every.”

— Dan Shipper & Kieran Klaassen, Compound Engineering: How Every Codes With Agents

These aren’t demos - they’re products used by thousands of people daily for important work.

Whether you’re a solo developer or part of a team, this approach offers a path to sustainable, compounding productivity gains.

Ralph Wiggum: The Official Claude Code Plugin for Autonomous AI Development Loops

Jan 3, 2026
Vibe Sparking

Ralph Wiggum: The Official Claude Code Plugin for Autonomous AI Development Loops

Section titled “Ralph Wiggum: The Official Claude Code Plugin for Autonomous AI Development Loops”

Introduction: Ralph is Just a Bash Loop

Section titled “Introduction: Ralph is Just a Bash Loop”

In the world of AI-assisted development, a fascinating technique has emerged from the mind of Geoffrey Huntley. Named after the famously persistent Ralph Wiggum from The Simpsons, the Ralph Wiggum technique embodies a simple yet powerful philosophy: keep trying until you succeed.

As Huntley famously describes it:

“Ralph is a Bash loop” - a simple while true that repeatedly feeds an AI agent a prompt file, allowing it to iteratively improve its work until completion.

Now, Anthropic has released an official Claude Code plugin that implements this technique, bringing autonomous AI development loops to your fingertips.

Understanding the Ralph Wiggum Technique

Section titled “Understanding the Ralph Wiggum Technique”

Core Concept

Section titled “Core Concept”

The Ralph Wiggum technique is built on the principle of persistent iteration despite setbacks. Instead of trying to get everything right in a single shot, you let the AI fail, learn from its failures, and try again - automatically.

The traditional approach to AI-assisted development looks like this:

The Ralph Wiggum approach flips this:

How It Works Under the Hood

Section titled “How It Works Under the Hood”

The official ralph-wiggum plugin implements this using a Stop hook that intercepts Claude’s exit attempts:

The loop happens inside your current session - no external bash loops needed. The Stop hook in hooks/stop-hook.sh creates the self-referential feedback loop.

Key Features of the Official Plugin

Section titled “Key Features of the Official Plugin”

1. Self-Referential Feedback Loop

Section titled “1. Self-Referential Feedback Loop”
  • The prompt never changes between iterations
  • Claude’s previous work persists in files
  • Each iteration sees modified files and git history
  • Claude autonomously improves by reading its own past work

2. Simple Command Interface

Section titled “2. Simple Command Interface”

The plugin provides two main commands:

Starting a loop:

Canceling a loop:

3. Safety Controls

Section titled “3. Safety Controls”
  • --max-iterations <n> - Prevents infinite loops by stopping after N iterations
  • --completion-promise "<text>" - Defines the exact phrase that signals completion

Best Practices for Writing Ralph Prompts

Section titled “Best Practices for Writing Ralph Prompts”

The success of the Ralph Wiggum technique depends heavily on how you write your prompts.

❌ Bad Examples

Section titled “❌ Bad Examples”

✅ Good Examples

Section titled “✅ Good Examples”

When to Use Ralph Wiggum

Section titled “When to Use Ralph Wiggum”

✅ Good For

Section titled “✅ Good For”
  • Well-defined tasks with clear success criteria
  • Tasks requiring iteration (e.g., getting tests to pass)
  • Greenfield projects where you can walk away
  • Tasks with automatic verification (tests, linters)

❌ Not Good For

Section titled “❌ Not Good For”
  • Tasks requiring human judgment or design decisions
  • One-shot operations
  • Tasks with unclear success criteria
  • Production debugging (use targeted debugging instead)

Real-World Results

Section titled “Real-World Results”

The Ralph Wiggum technique has demonstrated impressive real-world outcomes:

  • Successfully generated 6 repositories overnight in Y Combinator hackathon testing
  • One $50k contract completed for $297 in API costs
  • Created an entire programming language (“cursed”) over 3 months using this approach

Philosophy Behind the Technique

Section titled “Philosophy Behind the Technique”

Ralph embodies several key principles that make it effective:

  1. Don’t aim for perfect on first try - Let the loop refine the work
  2. “Deterministically bad” means failures are predictable - Use them to tune prompts
  3. Success depends on writing good prompts - Not just having a good model
  4. Keep trying until success - The loop handles retry logic automatically

Installation and Setup

Section titled “Installation and Setup”

The Ralph Wiggum plugin is available in the official Anthropic Claude plugins repository:

Key files in the plugin:

  • .claude-plugin - Plugin configuration
  • commands/ - Command definitions (/ralph-loop, /cancel-ralph)
  • hooks/stop-hook.sh - The magic that makes the loop work
  • scripts/ - Supporting scripts

Advanced Usage: Ralph Orchestrator

Section titled “Advanced Usage: Ralph Orchestrator”

For more complex workflows, the Ralph Orchestrator provides enhanced functionality:

  • Web-based interface for managing multiple Ralph loops
  • Parallel execution of multiple tasks
  • Progress monitoring and logging
  • Integration with CI/CD pipelines

Learn more about Ralph Orchestrator

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

The Ralph Wiggum plugin represents a paradigm shift in how we think about AI-assisted development. Instead of treating AI as a one-shot tool, it embraces the reality that software development is iterative - and AI should be too.

By letting Claude fail, learn, and try again automatically, we unlock a level of autonomy that wasn’t possible before. Whether you’re building a REST API, generating test suites, or working on a complex multi-phase project, Ralph Wiggum gives you the power to define the destination and let AI find the path.

References

Section titled “References”

  • Original Technique by Geoffrey Huntley
  • Ralph Orchestrator
  • Awesome Claude Guide
  • DeepWiki Documentation

Faster-Whisper: 4x Faster Speech Transcription with CTranslate2

Jan 1, 2026
Vibe Sparking

Speech-to-text technology has evolved rapidly since OpenAI released Whisper in 2022. While the original Whisper implementation set new standards for accuracy, its performance characteristics made it challenging for production deployments—especially for real-time applications and resource-constrained environments.

Enter faster-whisper by SYSTRAN—a complete reimplementation using CTranslate2 that delivers up to 4x faster transcription while maintaining accuracy and using significantly less memory.

What is Faster-Whisper?

Section titled “What is Faster-Whisper?”

Faster-whisper is a reimplementation of OpenAI’s Whisper model using CTranslate2, a high-performance inference engine optimized for Transformer models. The result is a drop-in replacement that:

  • Runs up to 4x faster than the original OpenAI implementation
  • Uses less memory with int8 quantization support on both CPU and GPU
  • Maintains identical accuracy—same model weights, just better execution
  • Removes FFmpeg dependency—uses PyAV for audio decoding instead

Performance Benchmarks

Section titled “Performance Benchmarks”

The performance improvements are substantial. Here are the official benchmarks for transcribing 13 minutes of audio:

GPU Performance (NVIDIA RTX 3070 Ti 8GB)

Section titled “GPU Performance (NVIDIA RTX 3070 Ti 8GB)”
ImplementationPrecisionBeam SizeTimeVRAM Usage
openai/whisperfp1652m23s4708MB
whisper.cppfp1651m05s4127MB
faster-whisperfp1651m03s4525MB
faster-whisper (batch=8)fp16517s6090MB
faster-whisperint8559s2926MB
faster-whisper (batch=8)int8516s4500MB

CPU Performance (Intel Core i7-12700K)

Section titled “CPU Performance (Intel Core i7-12700K)”
ImplementationPrecisionBeam SizeTimeRAM Usage
openai/whisperfp3256m58s2335MB
whisper.cppfp3252m05s1049MB
faster-whisperfp3252m37s2257MB
faster-whisper (batch=8)fp3251m06s4230MB
faster-whisperint851m42s1477MB
faster-whisper (batch=8)int8551s3608MB

Key Takeaway: With batched inference and int8 quantization, faster-whisper can transcribe 13 minutes of audio in just 16 seconds—nearly 8x faster than real-time!

Installation and Setup

Section titled “Installation and Setup”

Basic Installation

Section titled “Basic Installation”

That’s it! Unlike openai-whisper, FFmpeg is not required as a system dependency.

GPU Support

Section titled “GPU Support”

For GPU acceleration with CUDA 12:

Note: The latest CTranslate2 only supports CUDA 12. For CUDA 11, downgrade to ctranslate2==3.24.0.

Usage Examples

Section titled “Usage Examples”

Basic Transcription

Section titled “Basic Transcription”

Batched Transcription (Recommended for Production)

Section titled “Batched Transcription (Recommended for Production)”

Word-Level Timestamps

Section titled “Word-Level Timestamps”

VAD Filter (Remove Silence)

Section titled “VAD Filter (Remove Silence)”

Model Options

Section titled “Model Options”
ModelSizeUse Case
tiny~40MBQuick drafts, low accuracy
base~75MBGeneral use, balanced
small~250MBBetter accuracy
medium~770MBHigh accuracy
large-v3~3.1GBBest accuracy (recommended)
turbo~1.6GBSpeed-optimized
distil-large-v3~1.6GBDistilled, faster inference

Why CTranslate2 Matters

Section titled “Why CTranslate2 Matters”

CTranslate2 is the secret sauce behind faster-whisper’s performance:

  1. Graph Optimization: Fuses operations and eliminates redundant computation
  2. Memory Pooling: Reuses memory allocations across requests
  3. Quantization: int8 support reduces memory bandwidth
  4. Batch Inference: Processes multiple audio chunks simultaneously
  5. Multi-threading: Efficient CPU parallelization

Production Deployment Considerations

Section titled “Production Deployment Considerations”

For Real-Time Applications

Section titled “For Real-Time Applications”
  • Use BatchedInferencePipeline with appropriate batch sizes
  • Enable VAD filtering to skip silence
  • Consider turbo or distil-large-v3 for lower latency
  • Use GPU when available

For Batch Processing

Section titled “For Batch Processing”
  • Use larger batch sizes (16-32) for maximum throughput
  • int8 quantization reduces memory with minimal accuracy loss
  • Consider large-v3 for highest accuracy when latency isn’t critical

For CPU-Only Deployments

Section titled “For CPU-Only Deployments”
  • int8 quantization is essential
  • Set OMP_NUM_THREADS to match available cores
  • Batched inference provides significant speedups

Community Ecosystem

Section titled “Community Ecosystem”

Faster-whisper has spawned a vibrant ecosystem of tools and integrations:

  • speaches - OpenAI-compatible API server with streaming
  • WhisperX - Adds speaker diarization
  • whisper-diarize - Multi-speaker transcription
  • WhisperLive - Real-time streaming transcription
  • Whisper-FastAPI - OpenAI-compatible backend

Comparison with Alternatives

Section titled “Comparison with Alternatives”

Memory Efficiency⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

Batch Inference✅❌❌
GPU Support✅✅✅

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Faster-whisper represents a significant advancement in making Whisper practical for production deployments. Whether you’re building real-time transcription services, batch processing pipelines, or resource-constrained applications, faster-whisper delivers the performance needed without sacrificing accuracy.

The combination of CTranslate2 optimization, batched inference, and quantization support makes it the go-to choice for developers serious about speech recognition in 2025 and beyond.

OpenAgents: A Plan-First AI Framework for Safer, Approval-Based Development

Jan 1, 2026
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

In the rapidly evolving landscape of AI-assisted development, safety and control have become paramount concerns. As AI coding assistants grow more powerful, developers need frameworks that balance automation with oversight. Enter OpenAgents by Darren Hinde - an open-source AI agent framework that introduces a revolutionary plan-first, approval-based approach to AI development.

Unlike traditional AI coding tools that execute commands autonomously, OpenAgents requires agents to propose their plans first and wait for human approval before executing. This simple yet powerful paradigm shift brings much-needed safety guardrails to AI-assisted development while maintaining productivity gains.

What Makes OpenAgents Different

Section titled “What Makes OpenAgents Different”

The Plan-First Philosophy

Section titled “The Plan-First Philosophy”

OpenAgents is built on a foundational principle: AI should propose, not surprise. When you give OpenAgents a task, it follows a systematic workflow:

  1. Analyze the request thoroughly
  2. Propose a detailed implementation plan
  3. Wait for your approval
  4. Execute incrementally with validation
  5. Delegate to specialists when needed
  6. Confirm completion and offer cleanup

This approval-based execution model addresses one of the biggest concerns in AI development: unintended actions. By requiring human approval before execution, OpenAgents prevents misaligned or harmful actions that could result from autonomous AI behavior.

Multi-Language Support

Section titled “Multi-Language Support”

OpenAgents stands out for its language-agnostic architecture. The framework works seamlessly with:

  • TypeScript/JavaScript - Frontend and backend web development
  • Python - Data science, machine learning, and automation
  • Go - High-performance systems and cloud services
  • Rust - Systems programming and performance-critical applications

The framework adapts to your project’s language and coding patterns automatically, making it a versatile choice for polyglot development teams.

Quality Built-In

Section titled “Quality Built-In”

OpenAgents doesn’t just write code - it ensures quality through automated processes:

  • Automatic testing - Tests are created and run automatically
  • Type checking - Validates type correctness before completion
  • Code review - Built-in security and quality analysis
  • Pattern compliance - Follows your coding standards from context files

Core Architecture

Section titled “Core Architecture”

OpenAgents uses a hierarchical agent system with clear separation of concerns:

Main Agents (User-Facing)

Section titled “Main Agents (User-Facing)”
AgentPurposeUse Case
openagentUniversal coordinatorGeneral tasks, questions, workflows (recommended default)
opencoderDevelopment specialistComplex coding, architecture, refactoring
system-builderMeta-level generatorCreating custom AI architectures

Specialized Subagents

Section titled “Specialized Subagents”

The framework includes a rich ecosystem of specialist subagents:

Core Coordination:

  • task-manager - Task breakdown and planning
  • documentation - Documentation authoring

Code Specialists:

  • coder-agent - Quick implementation tasks
  • reviewer - Code review and security analysis
  • tester - Test creation and validation
  • build-agent - Build and type checking
  • codebase-pattern-analyst - Pattern discovery

System Builder (Meta-Level):

  • domain-analyzer - Domain analysis and recommendations
  • agent-generator - XML-optimized agent generation
  • context-organizer - Context file organization
  • workflow-designer - Workflow design
  • command-creator - Custom command creation

After an interactive interview about your domain and requirements, it generates:

  • Custom orchestrator agent
  • Domain-specific subagents
  • Context files with domain knowledge
  • Custom workflows and commands
  • Complete documentation

4. Quality Assurance Pipeline

Section titled “4. Quality Assurance Pipeline”

Every code change goes through automated checks:

  1. Type checking - Validates type correctness
  2. Linting - Ensures code style compliance
  3. Testing - Runs and validates tests
  4. Code review - Security and quality analysis
  5. Build verification - Confirms successful compilation

Why Plan-First Matters

Section titled “Why Plan-First Matters”

Safety Benefits

Section titled “Safety Benefits”

The approval-based approach addresses critical AI safety concerns:

  1. Prevents unintended actions - No surprise file deletions or modifications
  2. Human oversight - Critical decisions require human judgment
  3. Transparency - See exactly what the AI plans to do
  4. Control - Stop or modify plans before execution

Enterprise Adoption

Section titled “Enterprise Adoption”

For organizations adopting AI tools, plan-first workflows provide:

  • Governance - Comply with data security and privacy requirements
  • Audit trails - Every action is documented and approved
  • Risk mitigation - Reduced chance of AI-caused incidents
  • Trust building - Developers feel more confident using AI

Sources: McKinsey AI Governance, WEF AI Safety

  3. Wait for your approval
  4. Implement incrementally with validation
  5. Run tests automatically
  6. Review code for security issues

  • Pattern detection
  • Incremental refactoring
  • Validation at each step

Section titled “3. Custom Domain Systems”

Generates complete AI systems tailored to your domain.

  • Multi-environment support (CLI, TUI, IDE)
  • LSP-enabled language support
  • Cross-project collaboration
  • Natural language interface

Future Plans: Support for other AI coding tools (Cursor, Claude Code) will be added after stabilizing the OpenCode integration.

  • License: MIT
  • Contributing: Contributing Guide
  • Releases: 5 releases published

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

OpenAgents represents a thoughtful approach to AI-assisted development that prioritizes safety without sacrificing productivity. Its plan-first, approval-based workflow addresses legitimate concerns about autonomous AI behavior while enabling developers to leverage AI’s capabilities confidently.

As AI tools become more powerful, frameworks like OpenAgents that provide guardrails and oversight will be essential for responsible AI adoption in software development. Whether you’re an individual developer or part of an enterprise team, OpenAgents offers a path to AI-assisted development that doesn’t require surrendering control.

UI/UX Pro Max is a searchable design database that provides instant access to professional UI/UX knowledge. Think of it as having a senior designer looking over your shoulder, ready to suggest the perfect color palette, typography combination, or UX pattern for your specific use case.

Practical Review: Building HeartPetBond App with Claude Code + BMAD + GLM-4.7

Dec 31, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Core Insight: Can Zhipu GLM-4.7 replace the expensive Opus 4.5 in the Claude Code environment? How does its 200K context window perform within the document-driven BMAD workflow? This post reveals the answers through the real-world development of the HeartPetBond app.

1. Motivation: Why This Review?

Section titled “1. Motivation: Why This Review?”

In the AI-assisted programming realm, Claude Opus 4.5 has been the undisputed king, but its high cost (approx. $15/1M input, $75/1M output) deters high-frequency usage. DeepSeek V3, while affordable, occasionally hits bottlenecks with ultra-long contexts (>128K tokens).

I aimed to verify Zhipu GLM-4.7, a strong challenger to DeepSeek V3, by developing the HeartPetBond app to test:

  • Long Context Capability: Can the nominal 200K Tokens Context support an entire project’s documentation and codebase?
  • Output Length: Can the 128K Tokens Output generate complex Flutter pages in one go?
  • Stability & Hallucination: Does logic crumble during continuous development over several days?
  • Cost-Effectiveness: How much money can it save independent developers compared to Opus 4.5?

Context: When using DeepSeek V3 with Claude Code + BMAD, I encountered errors like API Error: 400 ... maximum context length is 131072 tokens... when the context exceeded 128K. GLM-4.7’s 200K context might be the solution.

With over 10 years of Flutter experience and previous success generating the MoneyMind App using Claude Code + BMAD, I set out to see if this new model could handle the challenge.

2. Setup: Integrating GLM-4.7 into Claude Code

Section titled “2. Setup: Integrating GLM-4.7 into Claude Code”

Switching Claude Code’s “brain” is straightforward:

1. Install BMAD

Section titled “1. Install BMAD”

First, we introduce the BMAD (Building Multi-Agent Development) system, the core methodology that makes AI “understand engineering standards.”

2. Configure ZHIPU GLM-4.7

Section titled “2. Configure ZHIPU GLM-4.7”

Claude Code supports connecting external models via MCP or API adapters.

  1. Register and subscribe to the Zhipu BIGMODEL platform to get an API Key.
  2. Configure the default model in Claude Code (or related MCP settings) to point to GLM-4.7.

3. From Idea to Product: The Automated Workflow

Section titled “3. From Idea to Product: The Automated Workflow”

Following the BMAD workflow, HeartPetBond’s birth followed standard Document Driven Development. Here are the key milestones:

1. Initialize Workflow

Section titled “1. Initialize Workflow”

BMAD scanned the project state and provided a precise analysis:

2. Create Product Brief

Section titled “2. Create Product Brief”

After confirming brainstorming results, the AI generated the product definition:

It even locked in the tech stack: Flutter for cross-platform UI, GetX for lightweight state management, and Drift for local persistence.

4. PoC Verification & Performance

Section titled “4. PoC Verification & Performance”

After switching to GLM-4.7, I was most surprised by its “throughput speed” and “depth of understanding.”

1. Development Speed

Section titled “1. Development Speed”

In just 2-3 days, GLM-4.7 helped me complete 5 core pages for HeartPetBond (PoC phase):

  • Welcome Page: User onboarding.
  • Ready State: State checks.
  • Home Page: Core recording flow.
  • Settings: Complex configuration management.

The code pass rate was extremely high, rarely missing brackets or breaking logic even in deep Flutter Widget trees.

2. Token Usage

Section titled “2. Token Usage”

The cost breakdown is impressive:

  • PoC Phase Total: Approx. 300 Million (300M) tokens.
  • Estimated MVP: For 15 pages and App Store submission, estimated 3 Billion (3B) tokens.

Despite this massive volume, GLM-4.7’s cost is only about 1/7th of Opus 4.5. A Pro subscription (~¥200/month) essentially covers the MVP development needs.

5. Wrap Up

Section titled “5. Wrap Up”

The verdict from this field test is clear: Building mobile apps with GLM-4.7 + Claude Code + BMAD is entirely feasible and highly cost-effective.

✅ Pros

Section titled “✅ Pros”
  1. High Cost-Performance: GLM-4.7 is a perfect “affordable alternative” to Opus 4.5. It significantly outperforms DeepSeek V3 in daily coding tasks while remaining wallet-friendly.
  2. Long Window Stability: The 200K Context Window is real. It maintained clarity without “catastrophic forgetting” even after loading mass amounts of BMAD documentation.
  3. Engineering Ready: Works seamlessly with Claude Code’s toolchain to handle complex refactoring and debugging.

⚠️ Cons

Section titled “⚠️ Cons”
  1. Reasoning Minor Flaws: In very complex business flow designs, GLM-4.7’s reasoning chain occasionally misses a step compared to the meticulous Opus 4.5. This is manageable via human Code Review and clearer prompts.
  2. Multimodal Gaps: Current API support for multimodal inputs (images/files) is limited, requiring an additional zai-mcp-server configuration.

🔮 Final Verdict

Section titled “🔮 Final Verdict”

If you are an independent developer looking for a smart AI pair programmer that won’t break the bank, Claude Code + GLM-4.7 + BMAD is the combination to beat right now.

Life is compounding. Start building your bond today.

Apple App Store Review Rejection: A Painful Lesson from Carelessly Submitting the Wrong Version

Dec 31, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Apple App Store Review Rejection: A Painful Lesson from Carelessly Submitting the Wrong Version

Section titled “Apple App Store Review Rejection: A Painful Lesson from Carelessly Submitting the Wrong Version”

“Double-check your submission version. Don’t let carelessness ruin your hard work.” — A painful lesson learned.

As an iOS developer, the App Store review process is challenging enough. But the most frustrating rejections aren’t due to code bugs or design issues—they’re due to your own carelessness.

Today I want to share a lesson that left me full of regret.

Background: Resubmitting After UI Fixes

Section titled “Background: Resubmitting After UI Fixes”

In a previous article, I documented the entire process of using Google Antigravity to fix App Store review issues for MoneyMind. After much effort, I finally fixed all the flagged UI problems:

  • Hidden the non-functional edit icon
  • Fixed the text overlay issue
  • Ensured page style consistency

Full of confidence, I prepared a new version and resubmitted for review.

First Resubmission

Section titled “First Resubmission”

After receiving Apple’s review issue email, I followed the standard submission process:

  1. Open Xcode
  2. Update version number
  3. Archive the project
  4. Upload to App Store Connect
  5. Fill in review information

Everything seemed smooth, and I awaited the review results with anticipation.

The Email Returned: Same Issues

Section titled “The Email Returned: Same Issues”

A few days later, when I saw that familiar Apple email again, my heart sank.

Same review team, same rejection reasons, same UI issue screenshots.

How could this be? I clearly fixed all the issues!

The Truth: Submitted the Wrong Version

Section titled “The Truth: Submitted the Wrong Version”

When I logged into App Store Connect and carefully examined the submitted version, the truth made me want to hide:

The version I submitted didn’t contain any fixes at all!

In my haste, I didn’t carefully check:

  • Whether the submitted Build version corresponded to the fixed code
  • Didn’t do a final Smoke Test before submission
  • Didn’t carefully verify the consistency between Git commit and Xcode Archive

Damage Assessment

Section titled “Damage Assessment”

This careless error brought real losses:

Time Cost

Section titled “Time Cost”
  • Lost a valuable review opportunity (usually takes 1-3 days)
  • Need to requeue for a new review
  • Delayed the release of the bug fix version to users

Opportunity Cost

Section titled “Opportunity Cost”
  • Users continue using the version with UI issues
  • Affected app user experience and ratings
  • Missed potential version promotion timing

Mental Burden

Section titled “Mental Burden”
  • Self-blame and regret
  • Potentially leaving a bad impression on Apple’s review team
  • Lost confidence in my own workflow

How to Avoid the Same Mistake

Section titled “How to Avoid the Same Mistake”

From this lesson, I’ve compiled a pre-submission checklist to help other developers avoid the same error:

1. Version Verification Checklist

Section titled “1. Version Verification Checklist”

2. Create Verification Scripts

Section titled “2. Create Verification Scripts”

To ensure the submitted version is correct, I wrote a simple verification script:

3. Record Submission Information

Section titled “3. Record Submission Information”

Create a submission record document for each submission:

Submitting the Correct Version and Explaining

Section titled “Submitting the Correct Version and Explaining”

After discovering the error, I immediately took the following actions:

  1. Re-Archive the correct code version
  2. Upload new Build to App Store Connect
  3. Honestly explain the situation in review information

In the review information, I wrote:

“Dear Apple Review Team:

In my previous submission, I mistakenly uploaded the wrong version without the fixes. This submission includes all fixed issues:

  1. Hidden the non-functional edit icon
  2. Fixed text overlay issues
  3. Ensured page style consistency with other pages

I sincerely apologize for the extra work this caused. Thank you for your understanding.”

Being honest about the mistake is better than pretending nothing happened. Apple’s review team is human too—they understand that developers make mistakes.

Lessons Learned

Section titled “Lessons Learned”

This experience made me deeply realize:

  1. Carefulness is the most important quality — Technical skills can be learned, but carelessness requires constant vigilance
  2. Processes are more reliable than trust — Establish strict checklists, don’t rely on “it should be fine”
  3. Verification is a necessary step — Always verify your version before submitting
  4. Honesty when facing mistakes — If you make a mistake, admit it honestly and correct it

Advice for Other Developers

Section titled “Advice for Other Developers”

If you’re preparing an App Store submission, remember:

  1. Slow is fast — Spending 10 extra minutes checking is better than wasting days on re-review
  2. Trust your checklist — Even for simple tasks, confirm each item
  3. Document everything — Keep records of each submission for easy traceability
  4. Don’t be overconfident — Even experienced developers make mistakes

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

While this App Store rejection experience was painful, it was also a valuable lesson. It reminded me that in software development, technical ability is only part of success—meticulousness and a rigorous attitude are equally important.

I hope my story helps other developers avoid the same mistake. Remember: Double-check your submission version. Don’t let carelessness ruin your hard work.

Wishing everyone smooth App Store reviews!

pg-aiguide: AI-Optimized PostgreSQL Expertise for Coding Assistants

Dec 31, 2025
Vibe Sparking

pg-aiguide: AI-Optimized PostgreSQL Expertise for Coding Assistants

Section titled “pg-aiguide: AI-Optimized PostgreSQL Expertise for Coding Assistants”

In the rapidly evolving landscape of AI-powered development tools, one challenge has persisted: AI coding assistants often generate database code that is outdated, missing critical constraints, unaware of modern PostgreSQL features, and inconsistent with real-world best practices.

Enter pg-aiguide – an innovative MCP server and Claude plugin developed by Timescale (now Tiger Data) that provides AI-optimized PostgreSQL expertise to coding assistants.

What is pg-aiguide?

Section titled “What is pg-aiguide?”

pg-aiguide is an open-source tool (Apache-2.0 licensed) that helps AI coding tools write dramatically better PostgreSQL code. It provides three core capabilities:

  1. Semantic Search across the official PostgreSQL manual (version-aware)
  2. AI-Optimized Skills – curated, opinionated Postgres best practices used automatically by AI agents
  3. Extension Ecosystem Docs, starting with TimescaleDB, with more extensions coming soon

The Problem pg-aiguide Solves

Section titled “The Problem pg-aiguide Solves”

AI coding tools frequently generate PostgreSQL code that suffers from several issues:

  • Outdated syntax – not keeping up with modern PostgreSQL versions
  • Missing constraints and indexes – leading to poor data integrity and performance
  • Unaware of modern PG features – missing out on capabilities introduced in recent versions
  • Inconsistent with best practices – not following proven patterns from experienced developers

Real-World Impact

Section titled “Real-World Impact”

The pg-aiguide team conducted an impressive comparison test. When asked to create an e-commerce database schema:

  • 4× more constraints compared to AI without pg-aiguide
  • 55% more indexes (including partial and expression indexes)
  • PG17-recommended patterns – using the latest PostgreSQL features
  • Modern features like GENERATED ALWAYS AS IDENTITY and NULLS NOT DISTINCT
  • Cleaner naming & documentation – more maintainable code

Installation & Setup

Section titled “Installation & Setup”

pg-aiguide can be used in two ways:

As a Public MCP Server

Section titled “As a Public MCP Server”

Available at https://mcp.tigerdata.com/docs, it can be configured for any AI coding agent:

As a Claude Code Plugin

Section titled “As a Claude Code Plugin”

For Claude Code users, installation is straightforward:

Supported AI Tools

Section titled “Supported AI Tools”

pg-aiguide supports a wide range of AI coding environments:

  • Claude Code – Native plugin support
  • Cursor – One-click install available
  • Gemini CLI – MCP server integration
  • VS Code / VS Code Insiders – Command-line installation
  • Windsurf – Configuration-based setup
  • Codex – MCP server integration

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

Semantic Documentation Search

Section titled “Semantic Documentation Search”

The semantic_search_postgres_docs function performs semantic search over the official PostgreSQL manual, with results scoped to specific Postgres versions. This means AI agents get accurate, version-relevant information.

Extension Ecosystem Support

Section titled “Extension Ecosystem Support”

Through semantic_search_tiger_docs, pg-aiguide searches Tiger Data’s documentation corpus, including TimescaleDB and future ecosystem extensions.

Curated Best Practices

Section titled “Curated Best Practices”

The view_skill function exposes opinionated PostgreSQL best-practice skills covering:

  • Schema design patterns
  • Indexing strategies
  • Data type selection
  • Data integrity and constraints
  • Naming conventions
  • Performance tuning
  • Modern PostgreSQL features

Use Cases

Section titled “Use Cases”

Simple Schema Design

Section titled “Simple Schema Design”

Prompt: “Create a Postgres table schema for storing usernames and unique email addresses.”

pg-aiguide helps generate properly constrained schemas with appropriate indexes and modern PostgreSQL types.

Complex IoT Schema

Section titled “Complex IoT Schema”

For more complex scenarios, like an IoT device monitoring system:

“Generate a Postgres schema for an IoT device company. Devices collect environmental data including temperature, humidity, pressure, and other measurements. Each device has a unique ID and human-readable name. Analysis includes finding outliers, anomalies, and device-specific ad-hoc analysis.”

pg-aiguide helps design schemas optimized for both recent data analysis and historical reporting.

Technology Stack

Section titled “Technology Stack”
  • Python (66.5%) – Core server logic
  • TypeScript (23.1%) – Plugin integrations
  • JavaScript (9.3%) – Web interfaces

Future Plans

Section titled “Future Plans”

The project has an ambitious roadmap:

  • pgvector support for vector similarity search
  • PostGIS for geospatial data
  • Community contributions for additional extensions

Contributing

Section titled “Contributing”

pg-aiguide welcomes contributions in several areas:

  • New Postgres best-practice skills
  • Additional documentation corpora
  • Search quality improvements
  • Bug reports and feature ideas

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

pg-aiguide represents a significant step forward in AI-assisted database development. By providing AI agents with deep, versioned PostgreSQL knowledge and proven patterns, it bridges the gap between AI-generated code and production-quality database schemas.

Whether you’re a developer using AI coding assistants or a team building AI-powered development tools, pg-aiguide offers a practical solution to the persistent problem of suboptimal AI-generated database code.
